comment._content: I've been scouring Google and Wiki to see if I can get a match on the cap or collar badges to no avail.  As each officer was expected to provide himself with a horse it may be that these are infantry officers rather than cavalry.  There are two different regiments on display here, the chaps with the boots and jodhpurs have their rank markings on their cuffs while the officer on the right front has his on his epaulette.  Looking at the young man at the front and the other at the rere they look so young, their chances if they got to the front were slim to put it mildly.

comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/47290943@N03] the collar badges were often referred to as collar dogs, and a grenade with flames was a common motif for these badges for certain regiments like grenadiers, fusiliers and artillery. Early grenades had wicks or fuses that were lit before being thrown. By the way I think I rushed to judgement on these being artillery officers, the shape of the cap badge and the type of collar badge looks more like the Royal engineers and they happened to be in Waterford in 1915. This is a photo of a Lieutenant in the Royal Dublin Fusiliers with the flaming grenade on the collar and cap.

comment._content: Hi all,I posted the photo on the Great War Forum to see if I could get the members of the forum to I.D the gentlemen in the photo,the opinion is that they are Royal Engineers(as has been suggested)there is a doubt about the older officer to the right and the one seated in the front.The people on the forum are generally spot on and it would not surprise me if they came back with the officers names!As to the location I think it is the Infantry Barracks(the one opposite Mount Sion School)as the steps and building look like the officers Quarters which were at the back of the barracks towards Newport square,school friends the Brannigans and the Floods used to live in the officers blocks in the late sixties- early seventies and I remember the blocks well.

comment._content: The reason I was leaning towards the Artillery barracks was that a field company of Royal Engineers would have about 71 horses to take care of. A Royal Engineer signalling company would have had about 84 horses. as far as I know there were few if any stables in the Infantry barracks. I could be completely wrong of course (wouldn't be the first time)

comment.author: 39191857@N05
comment._content: Most of us think of the military in "uniform" in other words with each person dressed the same as the others with perhaps rank markings the only difference between them.  This shot is very illuminating in that officers were required to equip themselves to a large degree leading to a great deal of individuality.  The footwear of the five that can be seen is interesting, the chap on the left has the most straps I've ever see on his gaiters, the other two are wearing puttees a very basic form of leg cover/protection, the chap in the front has his own very individual boots/leggings that appear to be very soft leather.  Finally the older officer with the shoes and turn-ups on his trousers looks like he was an adjutant or administrator attached to the barracks rather than the unit the others are drawn from.
